Award.AwardTitle: Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics Scholars Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Minneapolis Community and Technical College, a uniquely diverse and urban Minnesota college, is providing a pathway to student success in science and technology through the MCTC Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics Scholars (S-STEM) program. This program helps create a more diverse, better-prepared STEM professional community by enabling not only eligible underrepresented, underserved students to succeed in science and technology, but also by enabling other high achieving students to further their education.

Previous NSF awards at MCTC have a strong history of student success; 89% of students participating in the S-STEM program graduate, transfer to a baccalaureate program, or are on track for graduation or transfer. This new support is enabling the institution to strengthen and improve its efforts by stepping up recruiting, serving more students, creating alumni support group and incorporating new campus resources. Improved recruiting strategies include leveraging digital resources, student clubs, and campus events concurrently to increase the pool of qualified applicants. New campus resources to be incorporated include integrated advising, tutors linked to courses, new student interest groups in STEM, and the MCTC Undergraduate Research Initiative.

The MCTC S-STEM project is creating a more diverse, better-prepared STEM professional community by enabling academically talented, financially needy students to succeed in science and technology. The creative and successful design of this project is based on combining scholarship monies with peer cohort and faculty mentoring support. The commitment of accomplished faculty from STEM disciplines, relevant administrators, financial aid staff, and student support staff, as well as top-notch facilities, support services, long-standing connections with baccalaureate institutions, and outstanding contacts in the local STEM industry make the program sustainable. Furthermore, the MCTC S-STEM Scholars program is also serving first-generation students, low-income students, students of color, and other high achieving students. In so doing, it is helping to prepare a diverse, well-qualified workforce that can strengthen both the regional and global economy. The results of MCTC S-STEM are reported via the MCTC website and faculty presentations at local and national conferences. The program is also leaving a lasting legacy by creating a network of program alumni to support STEM students, by increasing the diversity of students earning degrees in STEM fields, and by enhancing support services that benefit future generations of STEM students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Minneapolis Community and Technical College (MCTC), located in the heart of downtown Minneapolis, is an important local resource that provides an excellent and accessible STEM education to many underrepresented low-income, first-generation students. The NSF-funded MCTC S-STEM Scholars Program has positively impacted academic opportunities and success for a diverse group of students by increasing their retention in STEM fields. The program utilized a two-pronged approach of providing students with both scholarship money and specific STEM enhancing support strategies. The MCTC S-STEM program has been extremely successful, with 80% of participating scholars graduating in STEM or maintaining successful full-time enrollment in a STEM degree program. Scholarship recipients also showed an improved GPA and course completion rate as compared to overall MCTC population. The on-time graduation rate was significantly higher than that of MCTC overall or any of science student populations, with a p-value > 0.01. Through these efforts of MCTC and the NSF, we were able to address significant disparities of academic and economic opportunities in STEM among underrepresented and underserved students.

 

Students accepted into the program received support through the evidence-based strategies of peer-cohort community building and faculty mentoring.  Scholars discussed their academic progress, challenges, and new opportunities in monthly group meetings.  These meetings also included workshops in academic and career skills, panel discussions with successful S-STEM alumni, transfer specialists, and industry representatives in STEM, and presentations on internship and research opportunities in STEM.  Scholars also met twice per semester with a faculty mentor in their major discipline, forming relationships that supported their academic success and expanded their personal STEM networks.  In a survey of scholars, over 93% of respondents rated faculty mentoring and peer-cohort interactions as “helpful” or “extremely helpful.”  The success of this innovative, focused support system has significantly contributed to the emerging understanding of effective educational support strategies in STEM.

 

S-STEM scholars participated in a wide range of STEM activities and events at MCTC and within the local community. By requiring our students to enrich their educational experience outside of the classroom, and encouraging them to connect with the academic and larger community, we enhanced community-integrated STEM education and public engagement. Several of our scholars are first generation students. Through the program, they had unique opportunities to participate in STEM-related events, tour local scientific and technical companies such as 3M and University Enterprise Laboratories, and present their work at local, regional and national conferences like the American Society of Microbiologists General Meeting, among other opportunities. A new generation of engaged and connected STEM scholars will contribute towards increased scientific literacy and informed public policy at the local, national, and global levels.

 

The MCTC S-STEM Scholars Program also connected talented STEM students with hands-on skill-building opportunities in STEM internships and research experiences. A fruitful partnership with MCTC Career Services helped match scholars with paid internships in STEM and the MCTC Undergraduate Research Initiative provided students with the opportunity to have hands on experience in exploring science. These high quality STEM opportunities engage and challenge students, creating a well-prepared, intellectually vigorous science and technology workforce that will strengthen our national and global economy. Engaging students in undergraduate research and industry experiences also enhances their critical thinking and analytical ability as well as their professional communication skills, impacting their interactions in society beyond science and technology.  According to a survey of program alumni, these engaging activities are very effective with 89% of respondents continuing their STEM studies in total; 46% of these are pursuing STEM majors at the University of Minnesota-Twin Cities, 22% finishing their degree program at Minneapolis College, and the remaining 21% pursuing STEM majors at other institutions.  In addition, 65% of respondents are currently employed, with at least 41% holding positions in STEM industry.  Examples of employers include Cargill, IBM, and Unites States Department of Agriculture. It is vital that we prepare a diverse, well-qualified STEM workforce to fulfill the promise of our collective future and with a partnership with NSF, the MCTC S-STEM scholar program contributed to the local work force.

 With the increasing educational opportunity and scientific literacy at MCTC, we hope to contribute towards effective and well-informed civic engagement and public policy. Science and technology will be critical tools to meet and overcome the challenges of our current global society.
